title: pH and Acid-Base Calculations
description: Learn to calculate pH, pOH, and solve acid-base problems quantitatively
subject: Chemistry
achievementDescription: Master pH calculations and acid-base equilibria

text.introduction: Quantitative acid-base chemistry involves calculating concentrations, pH values, and equilibrium constants. These calculations are essential for understanding solution chemistry and many industrial processes.

sections.title: pH and pOH Scales
sections.content: pH = -log[H+] and pOH = -log[OH⁻]. At 25°C, pH + pOH = 14. Solutions with pH < 7 are acidic, pH = 7 is neutral, and pH > 7 is basic. Each pH unit represents a 10-fold change in hydrogen ion concentration. The pH scale typically ranges from 0 to 14, though values outside this range are possible.

sections.title: Strong Acid and Base Calculations
sections.content: Strong acids (HCl, HNO3, H2SO4) and strong bases (Group 1 hydroxides, some Group 2 hydroxides) ionize completely in solution. For strong acids: [H+] = [acid] × number of H+ per molecule. For strong bases: [OH⁻] = [base] × number of OH⁻ per formula unit. Use Kw = [H+][OH⁻] = 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25°C.

sections.title: Weak Acid and Base Equilibria
sections.content: Weak acids and bases partially ionize. Use Ka (acid dissociation constant) for weak acids: Ka = [H+][A⁻]/[HA]. Use Kb (base dissociation constant) for weak bases: Kb = [BH+][OH⁻]/[B]. For conjugate pairs: Ka × Kb = Kw. Use ICE tables (Initial, Change, Equilibrium) to solve equilibrium problems.

sections.title: Buffer Solutions
sections.content: Buffers resist pH changes when small amounts of acid or base are added. They consist of a weak acid and its conjugate base (or weak base and conjugate acid). The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation: pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]) helps calculate buffer pH. Buffer capacity depends on concentrations and the ratio of components.

questions.question: What is the pH of a 0.01 M HCl solution?
questions.explanation: HCl is a strong acid, so [H+] = 0.01 M = 1 × 10⁻² M. pH = -log(1 × 10⁻²) = 2.

questions.question: What happens to pH when you dilute an acidic solution by a factor of 10?
questions.explanation: Diluting by 10 decreases [H+] by 10, so pH increases by 1 unit (becomes less acidic).

exercises.title: pH Calculation Practice
exercises.instructions: Calculate the pH of: (a) 0.05 M HNO3, (b) 0.02 M Ba(OH)2, (c) 0.1 M acetic acid (Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵), (d) a buffer containing 0.1 M acetic acid and 0.1 M sodium acetate.
exercises.hint: For strong acids/bases, use direct calculation. For weak acids, use Ka expression and quadratic equation if necessary. For buffers, use Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

scenarioChallenges.title: Water Quality Testing in Ghana's Communities
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Access to clean water is crucial in Ghana. Many communities rely on wells, rivers, and treated water supplies. Understanding pH is essential for water quality assessment and treatment.
tasks: Calculate the pH of well water samples with known H+ concentrations
Determine if water treatment is needed based on pH measurements
Explain how acid rain (from industrial activities) affects the pH of rivers and lakes
Design a buffer system to maintain optimal pH for water treatment plants
learningObjectives: Apply pH calculations to real-world water quality issues
Understand the importance of pH in environmental chemistry
Connect chemistry to public health and environmental protection
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Ghana faces water quality challenges in many regions, with some areas having acidic or alkaline groundwater that affects taste, health, and usability.
